title: Palliative Care Telehealth Delivered Program of SUPPORT-D Intervention for Persons With Alzheimer's Disease and Caregivers Phase 2
description_brief: The purpose of this research is pilot test a nurse led intervention previously used in patients with pulmonary fibrosis and their caregivers in a new population (persons living with Mild Cognitive Impairment or Alzheimer's disease and their caregivers. The researchers hypothesize improving advanced care planning in this population will result in enhanced quality of life over illness trajectory and improve safety for community dwelling PWD/CG dyads. Findings from this study will inform additional necessary adaptations required prior to conducting larger scale powered randomized control trial.

groups.title: Intervention Group
groups.description: Number of dyads or individual caregivers who received SUPPORT-D Intervention

achievements.comment: Twenty eight dyads and 2 individual caregivers were successfully enrolled.
21 dyads and 2 individuals successfully completed the study 2 dyads withdrew consent 5 dyads were lost to follow-up

groups.title: Caregiver Group
groups.description: A Program of SUPPORT-D (dementia): The SUPPORT-D intervention consists educational materials will be presented in a format with enhanced content (face-to-face virtually delivered by nurse interventionist via telehealth (e.g., MS Teams), with printed booklet, and identical digital content (electronic pdf and recorded videos of printed content). The SUPPORT-D intervention will be addressed in four sequential sections including: 1) understanding the disease 2) caring for myself; 3) information for the caregiver; and 4) planning for the future. Within the four sections of the intervention seven topics are addressed included symptom management, understanding your disease, putting safety first, ongoing conversations, respite care, palliative care, and alternative treatments. Participants will attend a total of 4 study visits across 8 weeks (approximately every 2 weeks).

groups.title: Care Recipient Group
groups.description: A Program of SUPPORT-D (dementia): The SUPPORT-D intervention consists educational materials will be presented in a format with enhanced content (face-to-face virtually delivered by nurse interventionist via telehealth (e.g., MS Teams), with printed booklet, and identical digital content (electronic pdf and recorded videos of printed content). The SUPPORT-D intervention will be addressed in four sequential sections including: 1) understanding the disease 2) caring for myself; 3) information for the caregiver; and 4) planning for the future. Within the four sections of the intervention seven topics are addressed included symptom management, understanding your disease, putting safety first, ongoing conversations, respite care, palliative care, and alternative treatments. Participants will attend a total of 4 study visits across 8 weeks (approximately every 2 weeks).

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measures.title: Alzheimer's Disease Knowledge Scale
measures.description: 30 items (T/F) summed total of correct items higher score indicates higher knowledge (scores range from 0-30)

measures.title: Perceived Stress Scale
measures.description: 10 items (4 point Likert scale from 0-4) summed score across items with higher scores indicate greater levels of stress (scores range from 0-40)
measures.populationDescription: Row population differs from overall due to participants not completing all survey items.

measures.title: Quality of Life in Alzheimer's Disease Scale
measures.description: 13 items (4 point Likert scale ranging from 1-4) summed score across items with higher scores indicating better quality of life (scores range from 13-52)
measures.populationDescription: Row population differs from overall sample due to participants not completing all survey items.

measures.title: Caregiver Self-efficacy Scale
measures.description: 8 items rated from 1-10 mean score across items with higher scores indicating higher self-efficacy (raw scores range from 8-80)
measures.populationDescription: This is a caregiver only measure care recipients not assessed for this measure. Row total may differ from overall population due to participants not completing all survey items.

measures.title: Safety Assessment Scale
measures.description: 16 items on 4 point likert scale ranging from 0-4 summed score across items with higher scores indicating higher risk for accidents (scores range from 0-64)
measures.populationDescription: This is a caregiver measure only, care recipients not assessed. Row total may differ from overall sample due to participants not completing all survey items.

measures.title: Zarit Burden Interview
measures.description: 12 items (5 point Likert scale from 0-4) summed score with higher scores indicating greater caregiver distress (raw scores range from 0-48)
measures.populationDescription: This is a caregiver only measure, care recipient not assessed. Row total may differ from overall sample due to participants not completing all survey items.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Alzheimer's Disease Knowledge Scale (ADKS) Score
outcomeMeasures.description: 30 items (T/F) summed total of correct items higher score indicates higher knowledge (scores range from 0-30)
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: baseline, at study completion, an average of 8 weeks

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Safety Assessment Scale Score
outcomeMeasures.description: 16 items with response options ranging from 0 to 4. The minimum score is 0, indicating no safety concerns, while the maximum score is 64, indicating significant safety risks.

outcomeMeasures.description: 4 items (5 point Likert scale) average score across items higher score indicates greater appropriateness of intervention (scores range from 4-20)
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: at study completion, an average of 8 weeks

limitationsAndCaveats.description: Many care recipients did not believe PROMIS measures applied to them so they did not complete those measures. Some participants chose to not complete all survey items.

explanation_target: Reason: The described study is a nurse‑led, telehealth-delivered palliative care / behavioral intervention ("A Program of SUPPORT‑D") aiming to improve advance care planning, quality of life, and safety for persons with MCI/Alzheimer’s and their caregivers—not a drug, biologic, or cognitive‑enhancing pharmacologic treatment. The trial listing describes the intervention as behavioral and nurse‑led. citeturn1search0

Act: Key extracted details — Intervention: A Program of SUPPORT‑D (dementia), delivered via telehealth by nurses; Population: persons with MCI or Alzheimer disease and their caregivers; Aim: improve advance care planning, caregiver preparedness, and quality of life (palliative/supportive goals). This is adaptation of a previously published nurse‑led SUPPORT program for pulmonary fibrosis. These sources confirm a non‑pharmacologic palliative/behavioral intervention rather than a biologic or small molecule drug. citeturn1search0turn0search2turn0search8

Reflect: Classification check — fits none of the four therapeutic drug categories (disease‑targeted biologic, disease‑targeted small molecule, cognitive enhancer, or neuropsychiatric symptom improvement). It is a behavioral/palliative care intervention (non‑drug), so per instructions it should be labeled 'N/A'. No ambiguity: the trial registration explicitly lists the intervention as behavioral (A Program of SUPPORT‑D). citeturn1search0

Web search results (sources used): 1) Trial listing for NCT05501119 describing the SUPPORT‑D telehealth palliative program and trial details. citeturn1search0 2) PubMed article describing the systematic adaptation of the nurse‑led SUPPORT program for dementia (SUPPORT‑D). citeturn0search2 3) Original SUPPORT nurse‑led palliative intervention trial in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (background/program origin). citeturn0search8
